dialogue: Hello, I’m Michelle.
I’m Ingrid.
Let’s go inside.
Do you want to see your mother’s room?
Yes, please.
I made some coffee.
Thank you.
Did she tell you about me?
Of course she did. And she told me that you were very upset about not having met your father.
So, she told you about my father?
She did.
Don’t you think she should have helped him when he came back from the war?
She helped him as best she could. Your father came back badly damaged. He wanted to live in another city and start a new life. His plans didn’t include Martha or you.

And your mother accepted the end of their relationship. She just saw him in such a bad way that she kissed him to give him some peace. And that kiss turned into something more. You are the fruit of that moment. Michelle listens very closely to her and remains silent. Obviously she’d never looked at the situation from that angle. And her early hostility prevented her mother telling her about it in any detail.
My mother never told me anything about that.
It is a difficult thing to explain to a child.
She could have done it later.
By then you were so estranged that it wasn't possible anymore. Your mother was a teenager and she had a life to live… And your father went to San Diego and he made no effort to know you.
So, Ingrid, do you think I was totally mistaken about Martha?
You were very unfair, but no one can blame you for wanting to know who your father was… It’s a very sad story… very painful for both of you.
Don’t be too hard on yourself… Martha wasn’t a perfect mother.
No, she wasn’t… Can I stay here tonight?
Of course! This is your mother’s house.
I came out to listen to the birds…
Your mother would come out like this, at dawn, and lie right there, to listen to them too.
Look, it’s snowing.

The snow is falling… It’s falling on the lonely pool we never used… It’s falling on the woods where we walked and you lay exhausted on the ground. Falling on your daughter and on me, falling upon the living and the dead.
